description: A small, stocky parrot that is primarily green, with a brownish-grey head and bright yellow feathers under the wings, which are visible during flight.
temperament: Generally shy, quiet, and sweet-natured. They are less demanding than many other Poicephalus parrots and can be very affectionate once they form a bond.
loudness: Quiet. Considered one of the quietest Poicephalus species, they tend to communicate with soft whistles and chirps.
loudness_icon: <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="w-12 h-12 text-green-500" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="currentColor" aria-hidden="true" role="img" aria-label="Quiet"><title>Quiet</title><path d="M7 9v6h4l5 5V4l-5 5H7z"></path></svg>
vocalization: Not known for their talking ability, but they can mimic a variety of household sounds. Their natural calls are not overly loud.
dietaryNeeds: A high-quality pelleted diet, supplemented with fresh vegetables, leafy greens, and a small amount of fruit.
healthPointers: Generally a hardy species with a lifespan of 20-30 years. As with other Poicephalus, they can be susceptible to aspergillosis if kept in a damp or poorly ventilated environment.
housing: Excellent for apartments due to their quiet nature. A minimum cage size of 24"W x 18"D x 24"H is suitable.
